subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: QS news update
msgSnippet: ... My personal view on this one is that all -ing endings, including verbal ones (bathing, thinking), nominal ones (shirting, stuffing (as in what you put in a
messageBody:
Anthony Grahn scripsit:

> >2. Quickscript manual abbreviations
> >Should we implement QS manual abbreviations, such as #21iNG (instead
> >of -#26It-#21iNG) for the gerund-participle suffix "ing"? Do you
> >want to do these one-by-one, or leave them for you to do a global
> >update at some point?

My personal view on this one is that all -ing endings, including
verbal ones (bathing, thinking), nominal ones (shirting, stuffing
(as in what you put in a turkey)), and root ones (nothing) should be
written without a vowel except as needed to resolve ambiguity.
Read clearly uses It in all these words, but there are plenty
who use Eat, or who vary between one and the other, or who use
an intermediate sound. This is another neutralization, but unlike
the t/d and It/Et-before-nasals, it occurs in all accents --
there are no English words ending in -eeng or -eang or the like.

--
Her he asked if O'Hare Doctor tidings sent from far John Cowan
coast and she with grameful sigh him answered that http://ccil.org/~cowan
O'Hare Doctor in heaven was. Sad was the man that word cowan@...
to hear that him so heavied in bowels ruthful. All
she there told him, ruing death for friend so young, James Joyce, Ulysses
algate sore unwilling God's rightwiseness to withsay. "Oxen of the Sun"
